title: Inverses of Exponentials - scores and studying

content.question: ​Students in a statistics class examined individual student test scores for a large group of students. Each test score is paired with the reported time the student spent studying. The class observed that when study time doubled, test scores generally increased by <math alttext="5"><semantics><mn>5</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> points. For example, a student who studied <math alttext="2 n"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> minutes generally scored <math alttext="5"><semantics><mn>5</mn><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> points higher than a student who studied <math alttext="n"><semantics><mi>n</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> minutes. For nonzero constants <math alttext="a"><semantics><mi>a</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> and <math alttext="b"><semantics><mi>b</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>, which of the following types of functions is most useful in modeling test scores as a function of time <math alttext="t"><semantics><mi>t</mi><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math> studied, in minutes?

choices.label: ​<math alttext="f open parentheses t close parentheses equals a times b to the power of t"><semantics><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>·</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mi>t</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>

​<math alttext="g open parentheses t close parentheses equals a times log subscript b t"><semantics><mrow><mi>g</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>·</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mi>b</mi></msub><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>

​<math alttext="h open parentheses t close parentheses equals a plus b t"><semantics><mrow><mi>h</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>

​<math alttext="k open parentheses t close parentheses equals a plus b t squared"><semantics><mrow><mi>k</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>

content.answer: ​<math alttext="g open parentheses t close parentheses equals a times log subscript b t"><semantics><mrow><mi>g</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>·</mo><msub><mi>log</mi><mi>b</mi></msub><mi>t</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Construct new functions, using transformations, compositions, inverses, or regressions, that may be useful in modeling contexts, criteria, or data, with and without technology.
